metadata.title: Facile one-pot synthesis of Eu, N-codoped mesoporous titania microspheres with yolk-shell structure and high visible-light induced photocatalytic performance

IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 13707 S0926-860X(12)00325-0 10.1016/j.apcata.2012.05.044 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 SEM (a) and SEM of broken microspheres by crushing (b), TEM (c) and HRTEM (d) of N–Eu-0.1 (the hydrothermal time: 8h). Fig. 2 SEM (a) and SEM with higher magnification (b), TEM (c) and HRTEM (d) of N–Eu-0.1 (the hydrothermal time: 4h). Fig. 3 XRD patterns of N–Eu-0.0, N–Eu-0.1 and N–Eu-0.5. Fig. 4 XPS spectrum of N–Eu-0.0, N–Eu-0.1 and N–Eu-0.5. Fig. 5 Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and pore size distributions (inset) of N–Eu-0.0, N–Eu-0.1 and N–Eu-0.5. Fig. 6 UV–vis spectra of N–Eu-0.0, N–Eu-0.1, N–Eu-0.5, P-25 and N-P25 (the insert shows the optical photographs of all samples). Fig. 7 Decoloration curves of RhB solution by the samples under visible light irradiation. Fig. 8 Decoloration curves of MO solution by the samples under visible light irradiation. Fig. 9 Photocatalytic mechanism on the Eu, N-codoped TiO2 under visible light irradiation. Facile one-pot synthesis of Eu, N-codoped mesoporous titania microspheres with yolk-shell structure and high visible-light induced photocatalytic performance Jian-Wen Shi a Hao-Jie Cui a Xu Zong b Shaohua Chen a Jinsheng Chen a Bin Xu a Weiya Yang c Lianzhou Wang b ⁎⁎ Ming-Lai Fu a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Urban Environment and Health, Institute of Urban Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences, No. 1799, Jimei Road, Xiamen, Fujian 361021, China b ARC Centre of Excellence for Functional Nanomaterials, School of Chemical Engineering, The University of Queensland, QLD 4072, Australia c Fushun Research Institute of Petroleum and Petrochemicals, SINOPEC, Fushun, Liaoning 113001, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 592 6190762; fax: +86 592 6190977. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Tel: +61 7 336 54218; fax: +61 7 336 54199. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Eu, N-codoped TiO2 with yolk-shell structure was synthesized by one-pot method. ► Synergic effects of two dopants to improve photocatalytic activity were discovered. ► Yolk–shell structure allowed multiple reflections of light within interior cavities. ► The resultant material presented high visible-light induced photocatalytic activity. A new type of Eu, N-codoped mesoporous TiO2 microspheres with yolk–shell structure (TiO2@void@TiO2) was successfully synthesized by a facile one-pot hydrothermal method at low temperature (180°C). The physical and chemical properties of as-synthesized samples, such as morphology, crystal phase, surface elements composition, porous structure, specific surface area and optical response, were characterized in detail. The resultant samples were porous microspheres with a diameter of about 1–3μm, and were composed of a large number of smaller nanoparticles. An interior circular cavity in each microsphere was formed between core and shell to construct a special yolk–shell structure, and a large number of pores were produced in shell and yolk by CO2 gas bubbles resulting from hydrothermal decomposition of the urea molecules, which tremendously increased the specific surface area and the pore volume of as-obtained samples. The absorption edges of Eu, N-codoped TiO2 were extended to longer wavelength, which led to notable absorption in the visible-light region. The photocatalytic performances of all samples were evaluated by photocatalytic decoloration of rhodamine B and methyl orange under visible light irradiation (λ >420nm). Eu, N-codoped TiO2 with 0.1at.% Eu dopant showed the highest photocatalytic activity, the efficiency of which was 5 times higher than that of Degussa P25. The enhanced photocatalytic performance could be attributed to the synergic effects of many factors, such as high specific surface area, large pore volume and strong absorption to visible light, which were created by the Eu, N-codoping and the unique yolk–shell structure. Based on the above results, the mechanism of enhanced photocatalysis on Eu, N-codoped TiO2 under visible light was proposed. Keywords Titania Nitrogen Europium Co-doping Photocatalysis Visible light 1 Introduction As a promising material for environmental cleanup [1], hydrogen generation [2] and solar energy conversion [3], titania (TiO2) has attracted extensive interest due to its excellent properties, such as environmental friendliness, chemical stability and low cost [4,5]. However, the photocatalytic performance of TiO2 is limited by several factors, such as restrictive light absorption (only responsive to ultraviolet light with wavelength below 387nm due to its wide band-gap), fast charge–carrier recombination and low interfacial charge-transfer rate of photogenerated carriers [6], which severely restrict its practical applications. Ion doping and morphology control are considered as two of very promising strategies to improve the photocatalytic performance of titania. Anion doping, such as N, C and S, has been confirmed to be an effective method for extending the absorption edge of titania to visible light region [7–9]. While rare earth ions doping, for instance, Eu3+, La3+, can play the role of inhibiting the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes [10,11]. Therefore, codoping with non-metal ions and rare earth ions may be a good attempt to further improve the photocatalytic activity of titania through the synergistic effects of the two dopants. On the other hand, it is well known that the photocatalytic performance of titania can be improved by controlling its morphology and structure. To date, titania with different morphologies, such as rod, tube, wire, sheet, and sphere, have been successfully prepared. It is worth mentioning that titania with very complicated structures, such as core–shell [12], shell-in-shell [13], multi-shells [14], flower-like [15], have been synthesized by a variety of approaches in recent years, and it has been revealed these delicate structures can endow them with unique and intriguing properties. Remarkably, a special class of core–shell structure with a distinctive core@void@shell configuration, which is called yolk–shell structure, has attracted tremendous interest recently due to the great potential for application in various fields, such as photocatalysis, lithium-ion battery, and biomedicine. So far, numerous approaches, Kirkendall, template-assisted process, selective etching strategy, have been developed to synthesize yolk–shell structured materials, such as Pt@CoO [16], FePt@CoS2 [17], Au@ZrO2 [18], Au@SiO2 and SiO2@SiO2 [19]. These synthetic procedures are multistep and complex. Furthermore, it has been a continuous challenge to develop TiO2 with core@void@shell structure. Only very recently, TiO2 with core–shell mesoporous microstructure has been successfully prepared by a wet chemical method [20]. However, the doped mesoporous TiO2 with yolk–shell structure (TiO2@void@TiO2) has not been reported in the literature until now. In the present study, europium and nitrogen codoped mesoporous titania microspheres with yolk–shell structure were synthesized by a facile one-pot hydrothermal method. The morphology, crystal phase, surface elements composition, porous structure, specific surface area and optical response of the as-prepared titania microspheres were studied in detail, and their photocatalytic activities were evaluated by the photocatalytic decoloration of Rhodamine B (RhB) and Methyl Orange (MO) solutions. It is important to note that the as-obtained mesoporous titania microspheres demonstrated high photocatalytic performance under visible light irradiation (λ >420nm) due to the synergic effects of a number of important factors induced by Eu, N-codoping and unique yolk–shell structure. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of europium and nitrogen codoped TiO2@void@TiO2 microspheres The Eu and N codoped mesoporous titania microspheres with yolk–shell structure were prepared by a modified wet-chemical method [20]. In a typical process, 3.4mL of titanium (IV) isopropoxide, 4.8mL of glacial acetic acid (CH3COOH, abbreviated as HAc) and desirable amount of europium nitrate (Eu(NO3)3) were first dissolved in 30mL of ethanol to form a clear solution, 0.6g of polyethylene glycol (PEG, molecular weight 2000) and 1.8g of urea (CO(NH2)2) were then added to the above clear solution under magnetic stirring at 40°C to form a transparent solution. The solution was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave with a capacity of 80mL. The autoclave was then heated at 180°C for 8h and then cooled down to ambient temperature naturally. The as-obtained product was centrifuged, washed, and re-dispersed in water and in ethanol for three cycles, respectively. Finally, the product was dried at 80°C for 12h in an oven. The sample synthesized with this approach was denoted as N–Eu-X, where X represented the molar percentage of Eu–Ti. For instance, if a sample was doped with 0.1mol% of Eu, the sample was denoted as N–Eu-0.1. The sample without Eu doping (marked as N–Eu-0.0) was prepared with the same approach as a comparison. Nitrogen-doped Degussa P-25 (denoted as N-P25) was prepared by a process reported in previous publications [21] for comparison. Degussa P-25 and urea (molar ratio 1:2) were mixed intimately in a mortar, and then calcined at 400°C in air for 1h. Subsequently, the product was washed three times with distilled water and then dried at 80°C. 2.2 Characterization Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were performed on S-4800 (Hitachi, Japan) equipment. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) tests were carried out on JEM 2100 (JEOL, Japan). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded at room temperature with an X’ pert PROMPD diffractometer (PANalytical, Holland) with copper K α1 radiation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were tested on a PHI5300 analyzer (Perkin Elmer, America) with aluminum K α radiation. The nitrogen adsorption measurements were carried out at 77K using an ASAP 2010 analyzer (Micromeritics, USA), and the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore diameter distribution curves were obtained from the desorption branch and specific surface areas were obtained according to the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) model. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) absorption spectroscopies were recorded by a UV-2450 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan) equipped with an integrating sphere, and the baseline correction was done by using a calibrated sample of barium sulfate. 2.3 Experimental procedures of photocatalytic decoloration The photocatalytic experiments were carried out by adding 100mg of photocatalysts into 100mL of 10mg/L dye (RhB or MO) solution. The suspension was ultrasonicated for 30min, and then stirred for 30min in dark to obtain adsorption equilibrium of dye molecules before illumination. Then, the suspension was irradiated with a 300W Xe lamp equipped with a 420nm cut-off glass filter (removing the UV irradiation below 420nm wavelength). During the irradiation, the suspension was stirred continuously. For comparison, the commercial Degussa P25 and N-P25 were also examined under the same conditions. At given time interval, 3mL of suspension was taken out and immediately centrifuged to eliminate the solid particles. The absorbance of the filtrate was measured by a spectrophotometer (UV-2450, Japan) at the maximum absorbance peak (554nm for RhB and 465nm for MO). Note that in order to remove the possible organic substance in the samples completely, the samples were directly irradiated under a 300W Xe lamp in an oxygen atmosphere [22] for 3h before they were used as photocatalysts. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology Fig. 1 shows the SEM and TEM images of the as-synthesized sample N–Eu-0.1. It can be seen that these microspheres have diameters of about 1–3μm and are composed of a large number of smaller nanoparticles, which makes the surface look very rough. From the two broken microspheres shown in Fig. 1a, it seems that the microspheres have completely hollow structure as the yolk in the shell cannot be observed from this angle of view. However, the yolk–shell structure can be confirmed when the outer shell was cracked entirely and the inside yolk was exposed, as shown in Fig. 1b. Furthermore, the TEM image of microspheres unambiguously shows the yolk–shell structure. As shown in Fig. 1c, the pale interior cavities can be clearly observed between the dark center (yolk) and the dark fringe (shell), and each yolk is encapsulated by a thin shell with a thickness of about 10nm. The HRTEM image (Fig. 1d) reveals that the TiO2 microspheres were formed by the accumulation of nanoparticles with a diameter of approximately 20nm (marked by blue circle), and the interplanar distance calculated from the lattice fringes of the HRTEM is 0.35nm (marked as “d”), which corresponds to the d-spacing value of (101) crystal planes of anatase titania. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (inset in Fig. 1d) discloses the polycrystalline nature of resultant particles. The SEM and TEM images of other samples (not shown here), such as N–Eu-0.0 and N–Eu-0.5, display the same characteristics including surface morphology, yolk–shell structure and so on, indicating Eu-doping amount in the range of 0.0–0.5% did not lead to significant change. 3.2 Proposed formation mechanism of yolk–shell structure In order to disclose the formation mechanism of yolk–shell structure in this work, the hydrothermal time to synthesize N–Eu-0.1 was shorten from 8h to 4h (other parameters unchanged), and the as-obtained sample was characterized by SEM and TEM to explore the changes in morphology and structure. As shown in Fig. 2 , the crystallite nanoparticles of TiO2 microspheres are smaller (about 10nm in diameter, marked by blue ellipses in Fig. 2d) and the surface morphologies of TiO2 microspheres are smoother (Fig. 2a) due to a short hydrothermal reaction time in comparison with the images displayed in Fig. 1. A pale circle with width of about 120nm can be clearly observed between the dark center and the dark fringe from the TEM image shown in Fig. 2c, implying these microspheres possess yolk–shell structure. Compared with the cavities displayed in Fig. 1c, the void between yolk and shell is much smaller owing to a short hydrothermal reaction time. On the basis of these images (Figs. 1 and 2), it is speculated that the formation mechanism of yolk–shell structure in this work can be attributed to Ostwald ripening mechanism [20,23–25]. 3.3 Crystal phase and surface elements composition To determine the crystal phase of the as-prepared samples (referred to these samples with the hydrothermal reaction time of 8h, unless otherwise mentioned), XRD measurements were also carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . The XRD patterns indicate that all doped samples are predominantly anatase TiO2 with polycrystalline characteristic, which further confirms the HRTEM results. The strong and sharp peaks imply the good crystallinity has been obtained although the crystallization temperature of the hydrothermal reaction is as low as 180°C. No characteristic peak of europium compounds is found in the XRD patterns, possibly due to the very small amount of europium species in the sample. There is almost no difference between Eu, N-codoped TiO2 and N-doped TiO2 (N–Eu-0.0) from XRD patterns, implying Eu-doping has not resulted in great impact on the crystal phase of TiO2, which may be attributed to the fact that Eu3+ is difficult to be introduced into TiO2 matrix at the low temperature (180°C) due to its much larger radius (0.112nm) than the radius of Ti4+ (0.064nm). Therefore, it can be deduced that europium ions are distributed over the surface of titania. Based on the Scherrer formula, the average sizes of N–Eu-0.0, N–Eu-0.1 and N–Eu-0.5 are about 38.1, 20.5 and 12.6nm, respectively, which indicate that europium doping can inhibit the growth of crystalline size of TiO2. For comparison, the XRD patterns of P25 and N-P25 were also recorded (not shown here). About 24% of rutile is detected in P25 except for the main anatase, and the crystalline size of anatase is 24.7nm. No difference can be observed from XRD patterns between P25 and N-P25, indicating that calcining the mixture of P-25 and urea to produce N-P25 has no significant effect on the crystal component and the crystal size of P25. To obtain valuable information about the chemical nature of surface elements, XPS was carried out for the as-prepared samples. It can be seen from Fig. 4 that the surfaces of the three samples N–Eu-0.0, N–Eu-0.1 and N–Eu-0.5 contain titanium, oxygen, carbon and nitrogen, and the amounts of nitrogen are 2.76, 2.69 and 2.61at% by the XPS quantification, respectively, which means that urea can be used as effective nitrogen source to get N-doped TiO2 in this conditions, and the actual N-doped amounts in the three samples are not much difference. No europium is detected due to low concentration of Eu-doping in N–Eu-0.1, however, it can be clearly observed from the XPS result of N–Eu-0.5 that a Eu4d peak appears at 135.4eV, which indicates Eu3+ ions exist on the surface of sample. The magnified XPS patterns of the N 1s (inset in Fig. 4) reveal the N peak appears at about 399.5eV, which is consistent with previous reports where authors synthesized N-doped TiO2 by using urea as nitrogen source [26]. In fact, there has been a controversy about the assignation of N 1s peaks in N-doped TiO2. Asahi et al. [7] and other authors [27,28] claimed that nitrogen can substitute oxygen atoms on the surface of titania producing an N1s peak localized at around 397eV, which would be responsible to N-doped TiO2 and visible absorption. On the other hand, Yates et al. [29] and Gopinath et al. [30] suggested that the peaks at 399eV and above 400eV could be attributed to interstitial N-doping. Therefore, we can reasonably argue that the main peak at 399.5eV in this work is attributed to interstitial N-doping which would narrow the band gap, creating an additional defect state between the conduction band (CB) and the valence band (VB) of TiO2 [31]. 3.4 Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm and porous structure In order to investigate the porous properties of the as-prepared samples, nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured. It can be seen from Fig. 5 that the isotherms of all samples reveal a typical type IV sorption behavior with the hysteresis loops, representing the predominant mesoporous structure characteristic according to the classification of IUPAC [32]. Moreover, it can be seen that Eu, N-codoped samples (N–Eu-0.1 and N–Eu-0.5) have higher adsorption capacity than N-doped sample (N–Eu-0.0). The pore size distributions of samples are expressed in the inset in Fig. 5. It can be observed that abundance of mesoporous structure (5–15nm) has been formed by CO2 gas bubbles due to hydrothermal decomposition of the urea molecules according to the reaction equation of CO(NH2)2 +3H2O=2NH3·H2O+CO2. The specific surface areas (S BET) of N–Eu-0.0, N–Eu-0.1 and N–Eu-0.5 are 90.1, 102.2 and 101.7m2/g, respectively, which are almost twice as that of P25 (53.3m2/g), and the total pore volumes of them are 0.231, 0.372 and 0.391cm3/g, respectively, which are also apparently larger than that of P25 (0.105cm3/g). As well known, most of the wet chemical synthesis methods are followed by calcination of the resulting materials at high tempreture (usually above 400°C), which would cause a decline of the surface area. However, in this work, the final photocatalysts were obtained at low tempreture (180°C). Thus the high specific surface area and large pore volume can be reasonably attributed the low temperature synthesis process in the presence of urea. Specific surface area and total pore volume play important roles in determining the activity of photocatalyst because heterogeneous photocatalysis is a surface-based phenomenon [33]. Sample with larger specific surface area and total pore volume can pre-adsorb more organic molecules on the surface of sample, which helps to reduce the recombination of photogenerated electron and hole, and improves the efficiency of photocatalytic degradation [34]. Furthermore, the surface area can be correlated with the number of effective active sites. The increase of surface area means the increase of active sites on which organic molecules and intermediate products are adsorbed [35,36]. Therefore, it can be expected that the as-obtained samples possibly possess excellent photocatalytic performance due to their high specific surface areas. 3.5 Optical response Fig. 6 shows the UV–vis absorption spectra of all samples, together with P25 and N-P25 for comparison. The absorption edge of N-P25 shifts to longer wavelength and presents optical absorption among visible light region in comparison with that of P25, implying urea can be used as nitrogen source to realize the N-doping of P25. The absorption edges of doped TiO2 (N–Eu-0.0, N–Eu-0.1 and N–Eu-0.5) further shift to longer wavelength in comparison with those of P25 and N-P25, and they exhibit strong absorption in the visible region, indicating that these doped samples can be excited by visible light. The reason may be attributed to the appearance of some localized states in the band gap of TiO2 due to N-doping and the narrowed gap of charge transfer, allowing visible light absorption [37,38]. It is widely accepted that the nitrogen incorporation into the crystal matrix of TiO2 modifies the electronic band structure of TiO2, leading to a new substitution N 2p band formed above O 2p valance band, which narrows the band gap of TiO2 and shifts optical absorption to the visible light region [39,40]. Furthermore, the band gap narrowing behavior on nitrogen doping was clearly evidenced from the optical photographs shown in the inset (Fig. 6). Compared with white commercial P25, the colors of as-prepared doped titania samples are apparently changed into yellow due to the doping of nitrogen. In addition to the red-shift effect caused by N-doping, multiple reflections of light within interior cavities of titania microsphere with yolk–shell structure may be another important reason to increase their light absorption [41]. Obviously the adsorption of visible light is the basis of the photocatalytic activity under visible light. The optical absorption data implies that the Eu, N-codoped TiO2 microspheres synthesized in this work can be promising photocatalyst under visible light irradiation [42]. 3.6 Photocatalytic activity The cation dye of RhB is one of the most commonly used xanthenes dyes for textile industry and is well-known for its good stability [43]. RhB has been widely used as model pollutant to evaluate the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 or other photocatalysts [44]. In current work, the photocatalytic activities of all samples were evaluated by the decoloration of RhB solution without investigating the degradation intermediates in detail. For comparison, the photocatalytic activities of P25 and N-P25 were also tested. The decoloration of RhB solution versus photocatalytic time under visible light irradiation (λ >420nm) is shown in Fig. 7 . Only about 20% of RhB is degraded in 60min in the presence of P25. Compared with that of P25, the visible light catalytic activity of N-P25 is improved twice, and nearly 40% of RhB is decomposed in 60min. The photocatalytic activity of co-doped TiO2 is further improved, and N–Eu-0.1 presents the optimal efficiency of photocatalytic decoloration (almost 5 times over P25) among the three doped samples. MO is a very stable azo dye and has been used as a probe for photocatalytic decoloration [45]. In order to further confirm the photocatalytic activities of these samples under visible light irradiation, the photocatalytic decoloration of MO solution by these samples was also investigated under the same conditions and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . Compared with RhB, MO solution is more difficult to be decolorized. However, as shown in Fig. 8, the codoped yolk–shell samples present higher photocatalytic activity than P25 and N-P25. Similarly, the sample N–Eu-0.1 shows the highest activity among all samples (5 times over P25). As described above, both the decoloration of the RhB and MO over the photocatalysts prepared in this work show similar trends: the sample N–Eu-0.1 possesses the highest photocatalytic activity under visible light irradiation among all samples, which can be attributed to the synergic effects of a number of factors created by the Eu, N-codoping and the unique yolk–shell structure, such as high specific surface area (102.2m2/g), large pore volume (0.372cm3/g) and strong absorption in the visible light region. In addition, the reason why the decoloration rate of N–Eu-0.1 was larger than that of N–Eu-0.5 can be attributed to the fact that there is an optimal doping concentration for any dopant, as reported in a large number publication on the doping of TiO2, because the excess dopant will become the recombination center of the photogenerated electron–hole pairs, which is detrimental to the improvement of photocatalytic capacity. 3.7 Proposed photocatalytic mechanism Based on previous publications and our experimental results, we attempt to propose the reaction mechanism for the decoloration of RhB and MO on Eu, N-codoped TiO2 under visible light irradiation as follows, which is schematically shown in Fig. 9 . Firstly, electrons located in the localized N states are stimulated to the CB of TiO2 under visible light irradiation and correspondingly left holes in the localized N states (Eq. (1)), then these electrons can be trapped quickly by the Eu 4f level (Eq. (2)) [46,47], which helps to inhibit the recombination of electrons and holes. After that, these electrons will be scavenged by molecular oxygen to produce the superoxide radical anion O2 − (Eq. (3)) and hydrogen peroxide H2O2 (Eq. (4)) [48]. These new formed intermediates can inter-react to produce hydroxyl radical OH (Eq. (5)). In addition, the photo-generated holes formed in the localized N states react with hydroxyl groups and H2O molecule to produce hydroxyl radicals (Eq. (6)). Finally, dye molecules are oxidized by these oxidants and are mineralized into final products step by step (Eq. (7)). (1) TiO2 + hγ→TiO2(h+ +e−) (2) TiO2(e−)+Eu3+ →TiO2 +Eu2+ (3) Eu2+ +O2 →Eu3+ +O2 − (4) Eu2+ +O2 +H+ →Eu3+ +H2O2 (5) H2O2 +O2 − →OH +OH− +O2 (6) TiO2(h+)+H2O (or OH−)→TiO2 +OH +H+ (7) Dye+OH (or H2O2 or O2 −)→→PRODUCTS 4 Conclusion In the present work, a new type of Eu, N-codoped mesoporous TiO2 microspheres with yolk–shell structure was synthesized by a facile one-pot hydrothermal method. It was found that urea played very important dual roles as a provider of CO2 gas bubbles which were responsible for the formation of mesoporous structure in titania microspheres, and as nitrogen source for N-doping of TiO2 which introduced the localized states in the bandgap of TiO2, allowing visible light absorption. The 4f level of Eu played an important role in interfacial charge transfer and elimination the recombination of photo-generated carriers. The photocatalytic activity of TiO2 was improved impressively due to the synergistic effects of many factors, such as high specific surface area, large pore volume and strong absorption in the visible light region, which were created by the Eu, N-codoping and the unique yolk–shell structure. The results of this work may shed light on the deliberately designed material for more efficient visible light photocatalysis. coredata.dc:description: A new type of Eu, N-codoped mesoporous TiO2 microspheres with yolk–shell structure (TiO2@void@TiO2) was successfully synthesized by a facile one-pot hydrothermal method at low temperature (180°C). The physical and chemical properties of as-synthesized samples, such as morphology, crystal phase, surface elements composition, porous structure, specific surface area and optical response, were characterized in detail. The resultant samples were porous microspheres with a diameter of about 1–3μm, and were composed of a large number of smaller nanoparticles. An interior circular cavity in each microsphere was formed between core and shell to construct a special yolk–shell structure, and a large number of pores were produced in shell and yolk by CO2 gas bubbles resulting from hydrothermal decomposition of the urea molecules, which tremendously increased the specific surface area and the pore volume of as-obtained samples. The absorption edges of Eu, N-codoped TiO2 were extended to longer wavelength, which led to notable absorption in the visible-light region. The photocatalytic performances of all samples were evaluated by photocatalytic decoloration of rhodamine B and methyl orange under visible light irradiation (λ >420nm). Eu, N-codoped TiO2 with 0.1at.% Eu dopant showed the highest photocatalytic activity, the efficiency of which was 5 times higher than that of Degussa P25. The enhanced photocatalytic performance could be attributed to the synergic effects of many factors, such as high specific surface area, large pore volume and strong absorption to visible light, which were created by the Eu, N-codoping and the unique yolk–shell structure. Based on the above results, the mechanism of enhanced photocatalysis on Eu, N-codoped TiO2 under visible light was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Facile one-pot synthesis of Eu, N-codoped mesoporous titania microspheres with yolk-shell structure and high visible-light induced photocatalytic performance
